Award.AwardTitle: Design Principles for Engineering Biology - Hyatt Regency, Tysons, VA - November 11 & 12, 2015

Keasling, Jay D.

The goal of the workshop is to convene experts in synthetic biology and related fields to identify broad principles and methods to translate fundamental discoveries from synthetic biology into useful bio manufacturing platforms. It is anticipated that the workshop will generate new ideas towards the next steps of leveraging the potential of synthetic biology for new technologies.

The workshop will survey a broad array of topics, including protein folding, metabolic pathways, cellular and tissue engineering, and evolutionary forces, to identify new research and educational directions that can capitalize on advances in synthetic biology and lead to innovative manufacturing methods and products.

The workshop is co-sponsored by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of CBET, the Office of Emerging Frontiers and Multidisciplinary Activities, the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program of the Division of Chemistry and by the Physics of Living Systems Program of the Division of Physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On November 11, 2015, the National Science Foundation and the University of California, Berkeley convened a meeting of internationally recognized leaders in the field of biological engineering to discuss the current state of the field, aspirations for the field, and the necessary scientific, technological and educational advancements that would be needed to achieve these aspirations.  The meeting focused on five topical areas:

  1. Design and engineering of biomolecules
  2. Engineering Biomolecular Networks
  3. Engineering Cellular Processes
  4. Evolutionary Stability of Engineering Systems
  5. Engineering Multicellular Processes

The recommendations for scientific and technological advancements needed are:

  1. Develop programs for better physics-based computational models of proteins and foldamers and other biomolecules in order to rationally design folding, recognition, enzyme, solubility, transport, partitioning, and to provide meaningful uncertainties.
  2. Develop programs that combine protein engineering and computational modeling to design sensors, protein-protein binding, allostery, and the like.
  3. Provide funds for developing mechanisms that truly combine systems and synthetic biology in a meaningful way and exploit both the top-down and bottoms-up approach.
  4. Develop funding mechanisms for targeted modeling and data analysis competitions, which have been of considerable benefit in other fields of computational biology
  5. Create an objective center to test, reproduce, curate, store, and endorse mathematical models in biology.
  6. Create an objective center for enzyme screening and prospecting, as well as for developing standard assays for assessing the quality of engineered organisms and for maintaining a standard database for high value chemicals with associated challenges to be addressed.
  7. Develop standard languages for exchanging and storing biological models and standard procedures that are to be included in a typical modeling study.
  8. Create specific programs or calls for proposals targeting theory in biology.
  9. Encourage the use of theoretical foundations in biological projects.

10.  Implement means for counteracting publication bias against negative results

11.  Provide funding for modeling competitions.

12.  Develop programs for automated model development, including metabolic network generation and removal of thermodynamic infeasibilities, for rapid model generation.

13.  Genome-scale models of higher organisms that incorporate transcriptomics, proteomic, and metabolic fluxomic data.

14.  Develop models and other tools for microbial communities to describe their interactions and contributions.

15.  Develop tools that any biological engineer could use to design and construct in a heterologous host the most efficient enzymatic route possible between a starting material and the target chemical.  These tools should include accounting for costs incurred by transcription, translation, post-translational modifications, etc.

16.  Develop kinetic models that provide a computational vehicle for integrating all available omics data into a unified framework.

17.  Develop libraries of well-characterized genetic components for a variety of organisms that will be useful for bioprocesses and make them available to the community.

18.  Development of retrobiosynthesis software to map biochemical routes between any starting material and any product and suggest enzymes that can be evolved or engineered to fill holes in pathways.

19.  Resources for automating critical steps to increase the reliability of the engineering process and reduce human error.

20.  Fund collaborations between researchers and their intended users, and encourage partnerships across time scales.

21.  Fund development of a central facility, which would develop highly professional skills in maintaining pure uncontaminated stocks, and reduce labeling errors to a minimum, could mitigate much of the reproducibility problems encountered in many fields.

22.  Develop theory/modeling to understand the impact of the intracellular environment on genetic circuit behavior and predict failure.

23.  Basic research and development is needed to integrate advances in synthetic cellular engineering, informed by in vivo systems, with experimental and computational modeling of multicellular processes to inform intelligent design of multi-cellular systems.

24.  Develop proof-of-principle studies that apply the lessons learned from developmental biology toward the construction of synthetic morphologies, either through controlled interactions from smart biomaterials or the genetic engineering of synthetic regulatory networks with spatially varying input, output, and processing circuitry.

25.  Identify mechanical communication modalities across and between cell layers.

26.  Elucidate multicellular-level decision making processes and tissue size-sensing mechanisms.

27.  Develop strategies to understand, overcome, and leverage biological heterogeneity.

The recommendations for education and training needed are:

  1. Encourage coursework development at all levels that includes integration of the mathematical, physical and biological sciences: teach biologists physics, theory and simulation.
  2. Develop workshops for stardardization and communal blind tests of methods.
  3. Provide dedicated funds for education in systems and synthetic biology.
  4. Development of courses, programs (ERCs and IGERTS), and industrial internships in bioprocess engineering to train bioprocess engineers (BS and MS) for industrial jobs.
  5. Develop course materials to train students in probability theory. 
  6. Develop the next generation tissue engineer.
